definition:
Let $(\Omega, {\mathfrak{B}}, \mu)$ be a probability space, and let
$X,Y\in{\mathfrak{B}}$ be events.

The *conditional probability* of $X$ given $Y$ is defined as
$$\mu(X|Y) = \frac{\mu(X \cap Y)}{\mu(Y)}$$ provided $\mu(Y)>0$. (If
$\mu(Y)=0$, then $\mu(X|Y)$ is not defined.)

If $\mu(X)>0$ and $\mu(Y)>0$, then
$$\mu(X|Y)\mu(Y) = \mu(X\cap Y) = \mu(Y|X)\mu(X),$$ and so also
$$\mu(X|Y) = \frac{\mu(Y | X)\mu(X)}{\mu(Y)},$$ which is Bayes’ Theorem.
